I tried to see the charm in "The Big Lebowski" but just couldn't find it.  This movie is just way too bizarre.  I understand that the Coen Brothers are "The Coen Brothers" because of their unique style, but the mindless rambling of this script feels like a waste of time when compared with the Oscar-winning script of "Fargo" a year earlier.  It is unfortunate to see a quality cast that includes Jeff Bridges, John Goodman, Julianne Moore, and Philip Seymour Hoffman used to create such a mediocre result.  They also introduce great characters like John Turturro's Jesus and Sam Elliot's "The Stranger," only to disappear with less than 5 minutes of screentime.  There isn't anything wrong with the acting; rather, this is a script issue.  There is nothing wrong with a screenwriter using to profanity to create realism in a scene but this is a prime example of swearing for the sake of swearing, to the point that we become desensitized to the meaning of the words.  Several segments in this film have no purpose other than the glorification of crudeness.  If they eliminated all of the unnecessary dialogue, the constant flow of profanity, and the random departures from the plot, this film would be 8 minutes long.  I actually found the story to be pretty interesting, ridiculous as it may be, but its presentation was too bizarre to make any connection to these characters.  It is a shame because the rambling of the script distracted from a genuinely inspired performance by Bridges.  You might enjoy this film if you adore the work of the Cohen brothers; otherwise, "The Big Lebowski" will leave you disappointed, confused, and annoyed.

The Coen brothers are synonymous with dejected atmospheres, strange characters and unusual plotlines. They are not a pair of directors that resonate with many because their films often remain on one level and never change tone or break the mould. However, the genius of the Coen brothers is that with The Big Lebowski they completely broke any mould in cinema and created a bizarre, outrageous and memorable yet unfortunately baffling film.
 
The filmâ??s peculiar plot involves a mix of ransom, a bowling league, echoes of the Vietnam War, a case of mistaken identity and nihilism. The film is undeniably confusing as it is difficult to follow and understand what is happening without becoming lost in the abundance of characters, the unconventional dialogue or the inexplicable dream sequences.
 
The Coenâ??s stated that The Big Lebowski is loosely based on author Raymond Chandlerâ??s type of storytelling that is defined by its complexity and unimportant plot. One of Chandlerâ??s novels The Big Sleep was turned into a noir feature in 1946 starring Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall, but it was more about their star factor and relationship in the film rather than the actual storyline. It is so bloody hard to even know what is happening because there was not an emphasis on plot but more on individual characters. Essentially, The Big Lebowski follows in the same footsteps as The Big Sleep as the film is defined more so by its idiosyncratic characters. They keep you entertained the most out of anything that ensues because they are all so weird and nuts! Particularly the male characters leave an impression on you; not one of them could have been replaced by another actor that is how uniquely exceptional they are.
 
Jeff Bridges portrays the title character Jeffrey â??The Dudeâ?? Lebowski and he suits his role so well because he looks and feels so laid back like his character. In one scene he goes to a supermarket in a night robe, a vest, shorts, shades and slippers. Now how laid back and slacking can you get? His voice is mellow just like his personality and he has a face that says to you â??I canâ??t be worried about that shit. Life goes on, man.â?? His type of attire and lax appearance endears his character in cinema history as he often wears pyjamas, jelly shoes and does not care what others think about him. He has so many distinctive features that he makes a hilariously likeable protagonist.
 
John Goodman is Walter Sobchak, the loud-mouthed, temperamental Vietnam veteran whose line â??shut the fuck up Donny!â?? has probably defined the film the most. He gets himself vexed and goes to extreme measures to settle disputes (whipping out a gun so his bowling opponent does not cheat), but then suddenly he can be calm the next second and silent. Steve Buscemi portrays the unfortunate Donny who is an innocent, good-natured character who takes all the insults that come his way without minding. He is a noticeable character who leaves a mark on you even though every time he attempts to speak he is silenced or ignored. Off topic, there is an interesting theory developed about Donny that he is merely a figment of Walterâ??s imagination because no one except Walter does actually notice himâ?¦ food for thought. Anyway, the juxtaposition of the three main male characters is outstanding; there are so many distinctive features for each character but none merge together.
 
Unforgettably, John Turturroâ??s conception of Jesus Quintana is possibly one of the most hysterically memorable supporting characters there has ever been on screen. He is a child offender turned bowler wearing a pink jump-suit, a net cap, has a long little fingernail, shines his bowling ball aggressively and retains a think Cuban-American accent. Now that is bizarre ingenuity!
 
The dialogue is unconventional as it often strays into topics that have nothing to do with what is going on. It is led by what the characters want to or end up talking about, not what the plot forces them to converse about. This wandering of conversation does provide moments of laughter but the confusion of the plot prevents you from finding other moments comedic or stimulating because you feel detached form the proceedings. Effectively, films that arenâ??t plot-focused must have something else for the audience to indulge in.
 
The Big Lebowski has idiosyncratic characters that remain cinematically memorable but on first viewing, it is difficult for the viewer to accept this notion and therefore many will not enjoy it because it needs a few more viewings to be enjoyed. The reason it turned into a cult classic is because over time people understood it for what it really wanted you focus on; however, most people would not watch it again after watching it once. This flaw in the film functions, I would say, as population control for its fan base.
 
The Big Lebowski asserts itself in a repetitive Hollywood as a unique picture that leaves you confused and uninterested in the proceedings, but engrossed in the eccentrically diverse characters that have facilitated its cult classic status.
 
â??â??â??â??â??â??â??â??â??â??        5/10

The Big Lebowski, the highly anticipated and initially under-received comedy that followed the massive success of "Fargo", is by and large the funniest Coen Brother's film. Every detail, large or small, from cast to soundtrack choice, serves to accentuate the innate hilarity of the plot. Our hero is hardly fit for such a title, a dissident stoner with a penchant for Creedence Clearwater Revival, white Russian's, and his bowling buddies. This permanent burnout, who ten minutes previous to the opening action was just writing a bad check for under a dollar at his local corner store, is thrown headfirst into the dangerous realities of the Los Angeles underworld. Mistakenly made responsible for a massive debt to a porn king, a debt accumulated by a much richer, more successful, man of the same name, our protagonist is forced to participate in a non-linear series of twists, turns, double-crosses and greed simply to return to the insignificant state of being in which he enjoyed living. Thematically, this movie examines the role fate plays in the life of even the most ineffectual individual. A must see for the utterly too comfortable. 
Impeccably cast as "The Dude" (our protagonist) Jeff Bridges brings undeniable likability to a willing loser. Perhaps even more important to the comedic merit of the film is the decision to cast Steve Buschemi as Donnie and John Goodman as Walter, The Dude's bowling partners, who serve as a sounding board for The Dude's woes. Donnie, a perpetually submissive, weak-hearted, lemming who receives constant unwarranted verbal abuse from Walter, a boisterous, delusional Vietnam War veteran struggling with a divorce, anger issues, and when the appropriate time is to brandish a firearm. Their dynamic as a trio (or a duo and an abused dog) is the corner stone of hilarity in this feature. While all of the aspects of the plot have some degree of comedic sensibility, these bowling alley scenes are light, largely irreverent, and bring a little levity to what would otherwise be a fairly dark, stressful, film (due to the grave nature of consequences involved in the plot).
In the case of The Big Lebowski, the soundtrack is very significant with each song reflecting either the tone of the scene or highlighting character traits. T Bone Burnett, a consummate professional and legendary musical figure, was entrusted with the job of assembling a track list. What is rare is that some of these musical choices enhance the comedy of certain characters, for example, Jesus (played by John Torturro) a dirty purple-jump suit wearing sex offender and cocky avid bowler, is introduced mid-bowl to a mariachi version of The Eagle's "Hotel California". This helps to highlight the level of disgust our hero has for this fellow. Lest we not forget, The Dude "fuckin' hates" The Eagles.
In comparison to the Coen Brother's other comedies, The Big Lebowski is the funniest because all of these criteria mesh together perfectly. 2007's Men Who Stare at Goats was very well cast, with many of the same actors from this film appearing in it, but the script was dull, the characters were unlikable, and there was no special connection between soundtrack and movie. Raising Arizona, while painfully funny in its own right and arguably just as funny as Lebowski, (in addition to being a Nicholas Cage movie that doesn't make you hate the Coppola family) did not have all of the aforementioned factors culminate. No special connection between soundtrack and movie, and a lack of actor chemistry. 
It may not be that little things make a movie, but these little things make The Big Lebowski funnier. This is the best job the Coen Brothers' have done in making a comedy, and its re-watch factor is through the roof. The Dude Abides, and so do I.

There are a not insignificant number of absolutely classic movies that I have somehow missed up to this point in my life. The Big Lebowski was one of the more egregious examples. Was...until now. Keeping in mind that I have lived half my life being bombarded by slobbering praise and endless quotes from this cult classic, I tried to watch with as open a mind as I possibly could, taking special care to guard against too lofty of expectations. Having said all that, it is pretty damn funny. The characters are cartoonish in there actions and dialogue, and the story is ridiculous beyond belief at times, not to mention some extremely bizarre dream sequences that seem to exist only to not allow the audience to get too comfortable with the tone, but it all works. Jeff Bridges is perfect, as is John Goodman. The supporting cast all fit very nicely in their spots, regardless of how senseless their roles may be. The story is compelling, somehow. I have no doubt that with more viewings (and a few bong hits) I would grow to love this movie as much as everyone else. So, to the other guy who hasn't seen this movie, if you read this, go ahead. You won't be sorry.

The Big Lebowski is a big turn from the Coens' previous film Fargo, one of my favorite dramas of all time - it's an extremely odd and spun out tale of a trio of stoners retrieving a stained rug back, and it's a masterpiece to some and stupidity for others - myself, it's good but extremely overrated.
Jeff "The Dude" Lebowski, a stoner with a love of bowling with his dysfunctional buddies, gets a taste of infamy when he is confused for a cranky disabled millionaire of the same name, as he attempts to get compensation for a urinated rug taken by nihilists. The Dude's stupidity eventually puts a number of characters in danger, including the "Big Lebowski", The Dude's best friend with extreme PTSD and anger issues Walter Sobchak, and The Big Lebowski's slutty playgirl wife, who is kidnapped.
The Big Lebowski has an extremely large fanbase, complete with conventions and a full religion - I found it to be entertaining but not hilarious, not near as good as critics or fans say it is - it's something new from the Coens and it's arguable to say whether it really worked out - the film's pros consist of its wide array of dysfunctional characters and its unique and trippy dream sequences dreamt in times of worry by The Dude. Cons are some jokes that fall flat and aren't appealing to all - Big Lebowski is intended for a certain crowd and it didn't appeal directly to me, but it had its moments.

What a great movie. It's like the Coen brothers create movies just for me, the perfect blend of comedy and drama and action and excitement. There are so many lines of dialogue that are hilarious, but it's impossible to explain exactly why they are. There's just something about the way the movie proceeds that makes everything hilarious.

There are so many vivid, unique characters. The Dude is a marvelous creation, brought to life by Jeff Bridges. John Goodman's Walter may be annoying sometimes, but he's so funny and unique and great. Julianne Moore's Maude was one of my favorite parts of the movie; I love Julianne Moore to begin with, and something about her delivery of each of her lines was so funny. There was something physical about her performance, like in the weird scene where she's just rocking back and forth to increase chances of conception. Philip Seymour-Hoffman and Steve Buscemi were both great in supporting roles (Donny's death made me sadder than it should've).

Above all, this movie was just super fun. I laughed a lot, I had fun guessing where the plot would go, and I had fun watching all the strange visuals, like the camera view from inside of the bowling ball as it spun down the lane, or the Dude's hallucination. In the end, I don't have a ton of deep analysis for the film. I just had fun.

The Dude abides. The Big Lebowski is a really different type of comedy. At times it's really dramatic and at other times I'm laughing my butt off! This movie has awesome performances from Jeff Bridges and John Goodman. Their names stick in my head and whenever I see their characters anywhere I'll instantly think oh that's The Dude or hey that's Walter. There are a lot of great scenes of comedic genius such as the scene when they take back The Dudes rug. The whole rug running gag never got old and neither did the plot. The plot follows The Dude being mistaken for the "Big" Jeff Lebowski and gets his rug peed on and this leads to The Dude being ordered by the Big Lebowski to find his missing wife. Like I said, this movie is comedy gold, I'm saying everyone has a funny line and has a comedic element to the film. Any scene when they go bowling is hilarious. The villains in this movie are awful villains but still are really entertaining and funny. The cast was really good together and had really good lines. While I loved a lot about this movie, there were some way too over the top parts that kind of lost me for a second or two. Whenever The Dude was knocked out and had a really absurd dream it was kind of hard to figure out what was going on. While it's good to have a lot of fun with those scenes it's important to have me updated on what's happening. The story, despite those select parts never gets boring and never fails to make me laugh. The whole atmosphere of The Big Lebowski was colorful and really crisp and easy on the eyes. If you are into a really funny, entertaining and slightly odd stoner comedy, The Big Lebowski is your perfect movie. A-

If I had to choose my favourite Coen Brothers' film, it would be Fargo. However, if I had to pick the one which most embodied everything Coen, it would be The Big Lebowski, the story of a guy, "The Dude" (played perfectly, as always, by Jeff Bridges) whose world starts going a little haywire, and only gets worse from there, with a collection of equally Coen characters (including a female artist who seems obsessed with vaginas, a wheelchair bound millionaire with a prejudice against bums and a Vietnam vet who seems to think that he can manufacture the war into any argument, from drinking coffee to buying an urn) who seem to try to make The Dude's life difficult. 

If you're not a Coen brother's fan then I don't know if you should even attempt watching this. And if you only sort of liked Fargo, don't take that as a recommenation to watch this. The inane plotlines, the awkward pauses, the baffling, out-of-nowhere instances, all of them will leave you dazed and confused, even if you're paying attention, so if you're not up for a second viewing, you might as well not watch it in the first place. However, if all that happens in the mind of the Coens (the Coenverse) makes sense to you (not likely), or you enjoy it, then this is definitely for you. 

We pick up the story with the Dude, with one of the best character introductions ever, as he comes home to be beaten up and have his rug peed on. This, along with some encouragement from his good friend Walter (John Goodman having the time of his life), inspires him to find the real Jeffery Lebowski and ask him for compensation. Even though he turns him down, Jeffery decides to ask the Dude for his help in delivering a ransom to his wife's kidnappers. Then the ridiculousness begins in earnest, as Walter cinvinces the Dude to do more and more crazy stuff in order to keep hold of the million dollars. The story then gets a little bit more difficult, which I won't go into because of spoilers. Suffice to say that their are Germans, porn videos and a man named Jackie Treehorn involved. 

This movie, however, is about four people, Bridges, Goodman and the Coens. You almost feel as if Joel and Ethan are sitting behind you sniggering as you get more and more confused with each scene. They put a camera in a bowling ball and roll it for goodness sake! Their script, too is confusing, with the most hilarious moments often being the most serious (e.g. Walter and the ear or the scattering of the ashes). 

If you can sit through it the first time without breaking something, give it a month, then watch it again. That's the standard opperating procedure with most Coen films, and this, as I said before, is the best one of all.

Review In A Nutshell: My previous viewing of The Big Lebowski let my feelings on the middle of the fence, unsure of whether or not my experience was an enjoyable one. The second time around did help me understand the elements that I did and did not like about this film, but it did not put me in a state of gratification that many seem to find from this film. The Big Lebowski is definitely a fun film, and arguably it is the brothers in their most playful (though I have yet to see Raising Arizona or Burn After Reading), and sadly it just wasn't enough for me. I am a fun guy, and I can watch films without getting too high-brow in its content; I love aimless films like Pulp Fiction and Inglourious Basterds, as they are filled with quirky and hilarious characters that only few people have the imagination or courage to paint on screen. The Big Lebowski does have its generous share of hilariously quirky characters, with Brandt being my unquestionable favourite, and the film does a great job in having each of them have their moment to shine and be related to the film's narrative; aside from probably Jesus, whom which I cannot seem to fathom on the character's sole purpose. Playful scenes and funny dialogue are found in every turn, with a layer of surprise in each one. Even with all of these strong elements that I have just stated, why can't I still adore this film? It has something to do with the film's story being too convoluted by the time it reaches to its final act. The film aimed to start itself off telling a North By Northwest style of story, with a man who unexpectedly out of his control has been placed in an awful situation, thugs assaulting him, pissing on his rug, thinking he was the Big Lebowski; this would be the film's protagonist, Jeffrey Lebowski, better named The Dude. The Dude then attempts to gain social justice by asking the actual Big Lebowski to replace what was damaged. Then as more of the story unfolds, the film eventually starts to build and eventually The Dude finds himself in a situation that he never wanted to be in. The Big Lebowski tells a story that is too large and erratic for its own good, if it kept its plot straight-forward and featured less characters, or better yet antagonists, then I probably wouldn't have too much of a problem with this film. Though underneath the film's playful plot, I was able to find some interesting aspects that the Coen brothers were exploring. It was interesting to see the film tackling once again the idea of greed and its relationship with corruption. In Fargo, we could see greed cause corruption in the souls of the characters, but The Big Lebowski shows corruption taking place outside of their own; each individual that Lebowski meets seem to have their own agenda in order to feed their personal desires, thinking that he is just a simple low-life that it does not really matter; and because the protagonist of the film written with such sympathy and not too self-centred, it was easy for me to identify with his struggles, and his aim to balance out the world around him. As I have said, The Big Lebowski is a playful film, and this statement transcends the most in regards to the film's acting performances. It is crystal clear that Jeff Bridges and John Goodman are having a blast with their roles, showing a natural vibe in their laid back attitudes. However, the cast members that brought the most comedic chops is actually Philip Seymour Hoffman and Steve Buscemi, playing roles that are low-key but when one pays attention to them, one would be left laughing until the scene is over. Julianne Moore, one of the greatest actresses of all time, felt out of place in this film; lacking a sense of presence or impact in her performance and trying way too hard to achieve that sense of sophistication that her character requires. I felt similarly with John Turturro and Peter Stormare's roles. The Big Lebowski may be a crowd favourite, and I can see why. I think if I saw this film during the time where I was at the initial stages of being a film enthusiast, or even before that, I might have adored this film to bits with its unorthodox characters and exuberant scenes.

This is a story of mistaken identity, a kidnapping, and the Dude who gets caught in the middle simply because he had a rug in his apartment that tied the whole room together. Clearly I'm late to the party on The Big Lebowski, but I did find it to be extremely funny and highly entertaining. I like how the story starts out small and slowly escalates. A big part of this is prompted by the Dude's best friend, Walter, played by John Goodman. He is easily the funniest part of this film. The way he talks to other characters, overreacts to things going on in the Dude's life, and continuously makes the dumbest decisions imaginable is what keeps this story rolling. Jeff Bridges is also great in the lead role, because he has that very laid-back vibe and I can totally believe he is the type of guy who literally does nothing with his life other than bowling. 

The only thing that doesn't work for me in The Big Lebowski is the fact that so many of the characters are completely insane. It starts to feel like I'm watching a live-action version of a cartoon when we have so many fantastical characters. Even the narrator makes a live appearance in the story, and offers nothing but strange cryptic dialogue. I think the story might play for even more comedy if it was a bit more grounded. If it felt like Walter was the only crazy in a normal world, it makes his antics that much goofier. Instead we get the crazy Maude Lebowski who, for no particular reason, decides she wants to have a child by the Dude. Or there is Jesus Quintana, who almost seems to flaunt the fact that he is a registered sex offender. Still, I can accept the strange world The Big Lebowski takes place in because I had so much fun watching. This is one film I would like to see again sometime, and I'd recommend it to those who are curious but have never watched it before.

The phrase, "Not appreciated in his/her/it's own time", is used quite often and usually in the realm of arts and entertainment. The Big L is one such piece of art. I finally bought this on Blu and it looks and sounds glorious. On the special features, Julianne Moore explains how funny she thought it was and that she had just been a part of something special but that most of the people she talked to didn't quite get it. John Turturro had a different story, he was one of the ones that didn't really get it. He thought it was funny but, him, like critics at that time, thought that movie lacked something their previous efforts like Fargo, had. He said it wasn't until he sat down and watched it with his son that really got it. And now he sees why it's such a comedic classic. So there you go, two different types of Lebowski watchers, the one's that recognize its brilliance right away and those that just don't get it. Though maybe those who don't get it, should take another look. I saw it with 10 people on it's opening weekend. 9 out of 10 didn't get it. I did. I laughed the entire time and loved it immediately. The 9 people with me thought I was nuts. The script is the most quotable and quoted since Casablanca and 16 years later, the soundtrack is still amazing, Jeff Bridges, John Goodman, Julianne Moore and Philip Seymour Hoffman are still robbed of Oscar Noms and the Dude still abides. One of my favorite movies of all time.

The Big Lebowski is a movie that's complex in it's simplicity. At it's most basic it's the story of a guy who gets mixed in with a kidnapping scheme all due to a rug, and at it's most complex there's a noir story any golden age director would be proud of. Of course, a good part of the movie takes place at the bowling lanes. As you can probably tell, this isn't the easiest movie to discuss, but that's all part what makes it so enjoyable. The best thing about the film is definitely our three bowlers, The Dude, Walter, and Donnie. These characters are so memorable and hilarious you could spend a day quoting their shenanigans. There's also kind of a problem with that though, sometimes it seems they're so good that they overshadow the rest of the cast. Sadly, The Big Lebowski sometimes suffers the same issue Trafic had, it's leads are so great the other characters can't keep up with them. They're not bad by any stretch of the word, but when you have to compete with the likes of a crazy war veteran and a hippie with words of wisdom you're gonna have some problems. Back on the good, the story told here is done great. It feels like you're seeing a crime story from someone who is confused about what's going on, and many times you'll feel just as confused as our protagonist. Also you actually start to become invested in everyone, and trust me, you'll tear up a bit at the end. There's also, of course, the insanely quotable lines and scenarios. If you forget about the diner scene or the car destruction then you're out of your element. Even characters the show up for a few minutes are classic, like the unforgettable Jesus and our narrator, the stranger. Overall, despite some flaws The Big Lebowski is a journey that's worth a few walks down, and you won't be forgetting it anytime soon.

The Big Lebowski is a witty contemporary adult comedy movie that had me laughing almost non-stop from beginning to end.  The film follows the life of Jeffery 'The Dude" Lebowski; an under-achieving, unemployed man with an interest in bowling and a knack for getting into trouble.  The film falls into the typical adult-comedy film genre with its cynical dialogues and adult themes revolving around sex, drugs, and murder.  The main plot of The Big Lebowski begins when two moronic thugs break into the home of Jeffery "The Dude" Lebowski, mistaking his identity with that of a millionaire with the same name.  The thugs pee on The Dude's rug before leaving his apartment to bully him into paying a debt that he knows nothing about.  The Dude takes the issue to Jeffery Lebowski; the wealthy man who the thugs originally intended to attack; in order to gain compensation for the ruined rug.  Mr. Lebowski offers The Dude a handsomely compensated job which involved the safe delivery of a ransom payment for the return of his allegedly kidnapped wife, Bunny.   The Dude accepts Mr. Lebowski's offer and quickly recruits the assistance of his friend and bowling mate, Walter Sobchak; a gun toting, Vietnam War veteran with severe anger issues and strong tendency to be violent and mischievous just to prove a point.  Walter and The Dude's antics and deception soon lands them into more trouble than either of them imagined. This was realized when their friend Donny Kerabatsos dies outside of the bowling alley during an attack by nihilist thugs.  Deceit leads to more conflict and before he knows it, The Dude seems to have everyone from Nihilist gang members to the Malibu Police Department to porn industry tycoons wanting a piece of him.
I believe that editing in The Big Lebowski was appropriate considering the fact that it was a film that involved a considerable amount of heavy drinking and drug usage.  There were multiple cut scenes that transitioned from The Dude's sober, conscious state to a hallucinogenic mind trip/dream sequence.  I deem editing like this appropriate because it helps the view of the film better understand how out of touch with reality The Dude really is, while at the same time adding a touch of silliness to the film.  Sound usage was also considerably effective in the film.  All background sounds effects were appropriate for the atmosphere of the scene and music selection typically consisted of "trippy" 1970's rock with a lot of twangy guitar usage to help the viewer feel the disorientation of The Dude's drug and alcohol induced hallucinations.  The scene where Donny died included fast German techno music with a lot of bass in the background.  This was done to help the viewer feel the increased drama of the action scene while the German Nihilist's were attacking.  Cinematography techniques in The Big Leboswski involved mostly realistic settings with a few hallucinogenic trip scenes that definitely fell into the non-realistic setting category.  All of the action and fight scenes involved shots where loose framing techniques were used to help express the energy of the scene.  The scene where Jesus was introduced involved several shallow shots where the background was blurred to show more focus on the character and his actions than the bowling alley and extras in the background.  
The social context of this film was set to show that being a deadbeat can be hazardous but entertaining to watch from a third party perspective.  There wasn't any deep, between the lines meaning or morals to been seen in The Big Lebowski, however it was still incredibly enjoyable to me.  I liked it because I find the drug based humor and crude white-trash comedy that this movie is primarily comprised of to be extremely funny. I would absolutely recommend this film to someone who has never seen it, simply because it is funny in an indecent sort of way.   I would rate The Big Lebowski 8 of 10 because it was funny and included a great cast of Hollywood stars.  I didn't give it a 10 because there weren't any truly incredible special effects or plot twists, however I feel that it was a great movie none-the-less.
Filled with witty dialogue, this cult classic is one of the greatest comedies of all time.

The Big Lebowski is one of those movies one has to see at least once, just so people stop telling you you have to see The Big Lebowski.  I finally did.  Its inventive, though not as much as its reputation.  Its clever, though again not as much as its reputation.  And thats kind of all that its got going for it, its all scattershot with no core of any kind.  Fortunately, some of the jokes do really land well, so its not a total failure.  How much one likes it may depend on one's level of esteem for the style of the Coen Brothers, as this movie is an example of some of their more famous traits without the leavening quality of substance and typical narrative.  I tend to like their movies, sometimes alot, but I don't love them.  When it comes down to it, all their movies are confections, very hard not to like but impossible for me to love.  This kind of film more appeals to critics, perpetually desperate for novelty, and to fans whose greatest esteem is for cleverness or perceived originality.  Like other Coen Bros movies, this one indeed has some cleverness and originality, but is even more of a sparkler on a cake than some of the other ones, with less lasting merit to it than, say, O Brother or Raising Arizona.  Definitely one to watch at least once, but whether its one to watch more than once, I'm not sure.

Quick review

This comic update of the world crystallised by Raymond Chandler charts the disastrous involvement of laidback dopehead Jeff 'the Dude' Lebowski (Bridges) in a kidnapping case involving the wife of his millionaire namesake (Huddleston). The Dude is hired as bagman and of course finds himself increasingly at risk as he makes his way about an LA populated by the rich, strange and dangerous. Nor do his bowling buddies help: Donny (Buscemi) is frankly several pins short of a strike; while Walter (Goodman), a crazed, irascible Viet vet, is so determined to stand his (and the Dude's) ground that he causes more trouble than he solves. Immensely inventive and entertaining, the film may not have the enigmatic elegance or emotional resonance of Barton Fink or Fargo, but it's still a prime example of the Coens' effortless brand of stylistic and storytelling brilliance. Thanks to Roger Deakins' gleaming camerawork, T-Bone Burnett's eclectic soundtrack selection and the Coens' typically pithy dialogue, it looks and sounds wonderful. Moreover, far from being shallow pastiche, it's actually about something: what it means to be a man, to be a friend, and to be a 'hero' for a particular time and place.

Great movie for quotes (Shut the fuck up, Donnie.) but generally not something a lot of people will appreciate on the first go-around.

I didn't care at all for this movie the first time I saw it - it wasn't terrible, but it wasn't what I expected.  By the third time seeing it, I was hooked.
The Coen Brothers' hilarious comedy about the carefree bowler "The Dude" and his quest for compensation for his soiled rug.
Gets better every time you watch it

Sharp dialogue, great characters, and a very peculiar story with a very peculiar way of telling it. Unexpectedly entertaining and in many ways just "cool", The Big Lebowski is one of the best changes of pace I have ever seen on film, taking some subjects and ideas that are executed with such professionalism that it is impossible not to recommend this film to any movie-goer.

The Big Lebowski is certainly an overrated film, but that doesn't mean it is bad. One of the funniest movies I have ever seen.  'The Big Lebowski' benefits from having excellent and memorable characters, especially The Dude played by Jeff Bridges and Walter played by John Goodman.  It also has a quirkiness that the Coen Brothers don't always venture into.  The story is basically about The Dude who is actually named Lebowski but also shares a name with a seemingly wealthy Lebowski.  The wealthy Lebowski charges The Dude to exchange a ransom for the life of his young wife Bunny (Tara Reid).  The Dude first meets Lebowski because two nihilists peed on his rug and had mistaken The Dude for a wealthier Lebowski.  Along the way, The Dude meets the enigmatic Maude Lebowski (Julianne Moore) who is not what I'd describe as prudish and who knows certain secrets about Lebowski.  Then of course, there is a lot of bowling.  The bowling brings up many hilarious situations that may not be related to The Dude's predicament, but it almost gives viewers a more human side to The Dude.  This cast is loaded with stars such as Philip Seymour Hoffman and Steve Buscemi.  Buscemi plays Donny, a friend and bowling teammate to both The Dude and Walter.  To the utter chagrin of Walter, Donny is often lost in conversation but he makes it up by being a great bowler.  Jeff Bridges is phenomenal as The Dude.  He is so easy-going, lazy, clueless, and hilarious, that you may believe he is like this in real-life.  The Dude is obviously the one who wants no part in a hostage situation.  Even eclipsing The Dude is John Goodman as Walter.  Vein, crass, and always eager to talk about 'Nam, Walter is hilarious and excruciating at the same time.  He never seems to help the situation but instead aggravates things.  Both of these men are great.  As one of the Coen Brothers' best, 'The Big Lebowski' will have you rolling on the floor.  Also, don't miss John Turturro as Jesus.  Ha.

"I'm the Dude."  A hilarious Coen brothers classic, and their funniest film ever.  Loosely inspired by Raymond Chandler's work, The Big Lebowski follows the bowling obsessed slacker Jeff "The Dude" Lebowski being hired by millionaire Jeffery Lebowski to deliver a ransom in order to save Jeffrey's wife after a case of mistaken identity leads to an attack at Jeff's home.  Unfortunately, Jeff's friend Walter prevents the exchange from happening as he schemes to keep the money, and the two run into trouble.  This comedy does it best at straying away from clichÃ©s to offer a fresh story of crime, greed, and morality to a desperate audience.  Lebowski uses Joel and Ethan's style of wry humor, eccentricity, and brutal violence, despite being less brutally violent than their classics Blood Simple, Fargo, and Miller's Crossing.  Luckily, there's enough graphic violence and language to keep audiences at the edge of their seats cheering and laughing their ass off.  There are nonstop laughs throughout, and there are moments that remain in forgotten today, and are made better with the sharp dialogue that make this a fresh crime-comedy (I guess it's fresh.  I don't really know.). The laughs are always deserved thanks to smart writing and direction from the brothers, and smart execution alongside the actors.  Joel and Ethan are able to keep the ransom the main focus throughout, as well as keep the storytelling top-notch and coherent.  They are also able to time each laugh with finesse, use Dude as many times as they would use graphic language, and craft unique characters.  They are also able to capture the look and feel of each scene, and execute each scene and comedic moment to a fault, showcasing some of their best work to date.  Under the alias "Roderick Jaynes", the brothers and Tricia Cooke add tons of visual appeal to the dream sequences that are both funny and help with the characterization of "the Dude", as well as remain convincing under a $15 million budget.  The soundtrack also helps with the scenes, and keep up with the rhythm of the film, and the acting makes it oh-so worth watching over and over.  All the actors live their roles as they were obviously written for them, Jeff Bridges and John Goodman being the best separately and together onscreen.  Bridges captures the laziness and attitude of "The Dude", showcasing his most recognizable role to date.  Goodman captures the outrageous temper and rage of Walter, and nails his use of quotes and violence to a fault, and both Bridges and Goodman are able to work together without any hesitation.  One of the funniest films of all time, and one of the best comedies of all time.

Eccentric & out there, The Big Lebowski certainly has all the right elements to make for a cult film. The character interactions are sharp, as is the dialogue and the plotting, but the overall sense I got from the film is that it's an acquired taste. It's just one I haven't acquired (as of yet). Insufficiently funny to be a comedy, and not deep enough to be a drama, The Big Lebowski feels like a film you have to be in the mood for, almost like you have to love it immediately or never. The ensemble cast performs good, especially Jeff Bridges, but nothing to write home about. If somewhere down the road I watch it again, I won't turn it off, but I won't be looking for a second viewing anytime soon.

This is one of the worst pieces of unfunny crap I've ever seen.  

The entire point of the movie seems to be to see how many times the word "fuck" can be worked into a sentence, and how many times this or that action can be referred to as "fucking (someone) up the ass" or "being fucked up the ass."

Now, I have no problem with "fuck" and its many variations; I use it quite often myself.  But merely throwing 15 variations of "fuck" into a sentence does NOT make it funny.  If a line is not funny without "fuck," it isn't any funner with it, either.

I'm also a bit of a "diehard"-- once I start to watch a movie, I watch it all the way through, even if it's quickly apparent that the movie is a piece of crap.  Not with this one, though.  After about 45 minutes, I became so fed up with the sheer stupidity and brainlessness of it that I said, "Why am I wasting my time on this crap?" and turned it off.

My only consolation is that I was watching a rented movie, and hadn't actually paid to see this pathetic piece of crap in a theater.

I hadnt seen The Big Lebowski in many years since the time I most recently watched it, but I remembered it being hilarious and predicted that to this day it still would be.

The Big Lebowski is genius because it takes the concept of a western story and turns it into one of the most original stoner comedies of all time. Through combining a case of mistaken identity, a complicated tale of kidnapping and a lot of characters with rich comedic potential, The Coen Brothers put out quite possibly their funniest film to date.
The story is a combination of complicated genres all merged into one hilarious comedic venture which is packed to the brim with clever twists and turns. Its a kind of comedy that only they could get so perfectly executed, and while it has a few bumps along the way it is consistently hilarious, unpredictable and very original.
The stylistic way that Joel and Ethan Coen form a comedy out of the story is iconic of them since it is full of eccentric characters in a weird universe of complicated crime. And their collaboration crafts a strong screenplay out of it. And as a team they direct the story to victory through a lot of hilarious territory and clever plot dynamics. Rarely do they miss the mark, because with such tenacious direction and writing The Coen Brothers manage to give it their all and make it all hilarious.
And they add their own touch of iconic visual style to the film as well, because The Big Lebowski also benefits from a lot of memorably imagery captured by fine cinematography which is one of the iconic elements of Coen cinema, as well as a wide colour palette which is most notable in the iconic dream sequence of the film. 
Of all the films by The Coen Brothers, The Big Lebowski is clearly one of their films more likely to appeal to a wide audience because it a laid back and relaxed comedy like if Clerks crossed over with Date Night, therefore it is less likely to alienate audiences like some of their significantly more melancholic pieces like The Man Who Wasnt There or A Serious Man. Its a lot more of a down to earth piece than some of their other features, but that doesnt mean that it lacks the intelligence or charm of their usual films because it is all still there in The Big Lebowski. Honestly, for anybody attempting to break into watching films by The Coen Brothers, I would recommend you watch The Big Lebowski first and I think you will be pleasantly surprised, because I sure was. 
And as common with a really good comedy film, The Big Lebowski is quotable for a lot of memorable comedic lines in the script which easily stick with the viewer and are the source of a lot of comedy.
But the most powerful talent at hand in The Big Lebowski under direction from The Coen Brothers is the deducated efforts of a hilarious cast all pulling their own weight.
Jeff Bridges delivers quite possibly his greatest performance to have not been nominated for an Academy Award. In the role of Jeff the Dude Lebowski he is so laid back and chill that its utterly hilarious. Youd never expect an actor who gets so dedicated to the involvement of his work like Jeff Bridges to be put into the relaxed role of the Dude, but he does it so flawlessly that its hilarious. The performance is hilarious enough, but to think that it is actually Jeff Bridges making such a chill comedic turn in the movie is just too funny. His performance is unforgettable and one of the highlights of his career, and is undeniably the funniest performance he has ever given.
John Goodmans performance is most likely the greatest of his career because his over-the-top nature is excavated and harnessed to maximum success by Joel and Ethan Coen, and not at one point does he ever come up short. His portrayal of Walter Sobchak is perfectly hilarious because he uses his ability for intimidation and aggression to characterise the man and he absolutely nails it with perfect comedic time delivery and an undeniably fierce dedication to character. John Goodmans energy is put on full display in The Big Lebowski and he is perfectly hilarious at interacting with other cast members and nailing the hilarious aspects of his character.
Julianne Moores supporting performance is one that is challenging to look away from. The instant she flies into the screen she projects a dominant sexual appeal overshadowed only by the sharp edge of her quick witted and intelligent line delivery. She makes an effort to dominate the screen whenever she is on it and it proves successful essentially every time because she exerts the talent that made her later go on to be deemed one of the finest actresses of her generation in The Big Lebowski. The Big Lebowski boasts one of her much younger and superior comedic performances, and her talent is no less than it later grew to be. Her role in The Big Lebowski is jut terrific.
Steve Buscemis small role of Donny was pretty good as well. His natural charm as an actor was good but the funniest thing about him is the fact that since John Goodman keeps on proclaiming to him Shut the f*ck up, Donny! which is a reference to the previous film by The Coen Brothers, Fargo. In Fargo, Steve Buscemis character could never shut up whereas in The Big Lebowski he rarely speaks, and this proves fairly funny.
The performances of David Huddleston, Tara Reid and particularly the late Phillip Seymour Hoffman all made key contributions to the film as well.
Lastly, the cameo by John Tuturro was the icing on top of the cake and had some real comedic virtues to it.

So The Big Lebowski is a hilarious stoner comedy classic with a lot of intelligence and some of the greatest performances ever given by Jeff Bridges and John Goodman in a comedy film.

This film is quite good. Every character is freaking awesome and the dialogue is simply golden. The one character everyone knows, The Dude, is easily the highlight of this movie. He's a lazy, easygoing guy who just likes to sit back and let life happen. When he gets mixed up into a crazy, complex plot, the results are quite amusing. The second best character is Walter, a foul mouthed, pissed off, Vietnam veteran. He makes for some hilarious and memorable scenes. The plot to this movie is kind of all over the place. It's never hard to follow or anything, but it is everywhere. I can see people making the argument that is was a really lazy to put such little effort into the plot. If that's your opinion, I won't argue with you. However, I will disagree with you. I'd say lots of effort was put into this plot. It seems that a lot of time was put into making it so it could be complex if it wanted to, but simple if looked at from a certain point of view. That lines up perfectly with the character of The Dude. He makes the plot seem that way. He only focuses on what he cares about and ignores everything else. That is actually quite brilliant and I give major points to the Coen brothers on that one. In the end, The Big Lebowski is a hilarious film, and should be seen by everyone.
Hysterical and classic. Instantaneously an all-time favorite for me. Thank you so much for the laughs Jeff Bridges, John Goodman, and Steve Buscemi! Oh and don't forget Flea!

Thought it subscribes to the Coen brothers typical aimless direction and pretentiously incoherent plot, The Big Lebowski rises above typical Coen projects thanks to plenty of laughs and a cast of wonderful and colourful characters, especially Jeff Bridges and John Goodman.

The Big Lebowski is not a good movie, as many a misguided viewer has opined. Rather, it is a bunch of good actors saying and doing funny things. But the film itself is disjointed with nothing at its center. It does, however, illustrate why the Coen Brothers are so very good.  Their movies still feature actors saying and doing funny things, but they're doing it in support of great stories that hold together as they move right along.

Both surrealist and funny.  I was amused by every single character.  I don't think I could pick a favourite.

The Coen Brothers definitely know how to make weird surrealistic fantasies for the moments when The Dude is drugged or knocked unconscious.  The plot is quite convoluted but somehow it makes for great jokes and meet-ups with intriguing characters.  

Walter kind of reminded me of Eric Cartman, fat, somewhat greedy and ready to take what he wants with violence.  He isn't the main character but he's definitely the dominant member of the group.  Steve Buscemi was also funny as Donny, constantly wearing a clueless expression and never committing to an entire conversation; he always has to duck in right in the middle of the conversation.  

I loved The Dude and all of the catchphrases in the movie, like "Shut up Donny!" or "That's, like, your opinion, man."  

It's not easy to describe what's so compelling about The Big Lebowski; maybe Jeff Bridges' character The Dude.  However, if you haven't seen it you should just watch it to see why it is a cult film.  It was very entertaining, with unforgettable characters and catchphrases.

This is just my opinion, but The Big Lebowski is an ace comedy. The Coen Brothers don't go for anything more than that, and for that reach, they win. Note the film noir-ish kidnapping scheme of the main story, yet the presentation never feels like an homage to, or parody of, the genre. It's presented as a farce, albeit with some blacker-than-usual jokes. I don't often quote films, so the fact that I quote The Big Lebowski is a testament to my strong liking for it. "This is what happens when you fuck with a stranger," is a quote I frequently use. Its context is much funnier than the line itself though, when Walter, played by John Goodman, so swiftly changes tactics from formal business meeting to wrecking a car. There are no cuts, meaning we can see this change in Goodman. And I adore it. Meanwhile, the freewheeling The Dude, played by Jeff Bridges, responds so entertainingly to his environment. A car following him? Drop the joint, oh shit I dropped it on myself, pour the alcohol, oh shit I'm driving, turn into that tree. These are human mistakes that we can only see someone like The Dude make, and for that, I was able to connect to the film by laughing at the expense of our two main heroes.

Note the classic contrast of Jeff Bridges and John Goodman -- The Dude is chill and genuine, while Walter is self-entitled and opportunistic. Where most comedies would define the friendship as healthy against the obvious odds, the friendship between Bridges and Goodman seems more convenient than anything else. They both like bowling, as well as fucking Donny (Steve Buscemi). That's it, really. At the end of the day, they are their own people and they aren't going to miss each other much, even if death suddenly were to strike one of them. The uniqueness in this relationship doesn't matter much though. Really, what counts the most is how strongly the actors accentuate their defining characteristics, thus making themselves so memorable.

To take us into the world of the Dude, there is a psychedelic feel to what surrounds the story and characters. We have a cowboy narrator, an acidic 1960s/1970s rock soundtrack, and even more trippy dream sequences. While certainly unusual and sometimes run for longer than needed, they do establish a legendary status for The Dude. Nearly 20 years after the film's release, I hear references, see shirts, and think to myself, "The Dude really is a legend now."
Perfectly cast, beautifully shot, and sharply written, The Big Lebowski shows Joel and Ethan Coen in top form. A true cult-classic, and one that should be hailed as one of the best of the decade.

One if the most twisted, convoluted yet outrageously hilarious comedies of all time, The Big Lebowski is a masterpiece from the Coen Brothers. What makes the film so great is how almost none of the elements add up and yet the film would not be as good if any of it was cut. As for the acting, Jeff Bridges is absolutely perfect as the Dude, the laziest man you'll ever come across, and John Goodman is fantastic as always. The directing even further enhances the comedic aspects of the film, as whole dream sequences adds new layers to the dude in the most awkwardly funny way possible. The pacing is fantastic, and the laughs are by no means few and far between. How Jeff Bridges was not nominated for an oscar is still impossible for me to understand.

One of the greatest, funniest and outrageous comedies of all time, The Big Lebowski delivers the comedy, the crime and the drama in this masterpiece from the Coen Brothers.

Jeff Lebowski aka The Dude (Jeff Bridges) isn't happy about a Chinaman peeing on his rug after a misunderstanding and in trying to solve his problems, gets wound up in a hostage situation with another Jeff Lebowski. Told to rescue Lebowski's wife from Nihilists, Dude has his buddies Walter Sobchak (John Goodman) and Donny (Steve Buscemi) to help him out.

The first striking image is of Jeff Bridges' legendary character of The Dude, bowler and White Russian drinker concerned about his soiled rug. It's a role in which he fits right into and Jeff Bridges excels his comedic talents in a great role. However, the show-stealer is John Goodman's Vietnam veteran, Jewish bowling partner Walter Sobchak, definitely one of the greatest comedy characters ever! Every quote is memorable and every scene involving him is an instant side-splitter. It is the role John Goodman will forever be remembered for. Steve Buscemi plays Donny, another bowling partner who is constantly told to shut up and John Turturro plays Quintana Jesus in a short but memorable role. The other cast members a pretty good too.

As is usual with anything the Coen Brothers do, the story is written very well and delivers a lot of unexpected developments. There are several dream sequences that are done really well. The visuals are great and each dream is different and memorable and funny. The dialogue is memorable a hilarious and definitely makes this one of the most quotable films ever.

Definitely one of my favourite films with incredibly funny and featuring awesome characters, The Big Lebowski deliver hilarious lines, awesome visuals and a great story.

When this film was first released, I could compare it to the then-unknown Tim Burton project Pee-wee's Big Adventure starring Paul Reubens in his famous persona, Pee-wee Herman. Both films received mixed critical reception. Both eventually became cult films. Both accumulated more positive reception over the years. But in a way I don't understand, Pee-wee's Big Adventure was more successful than The Big Lebowski during its release. As much as I respect Tim Burton (Sweeney Todd, The Nightmare Before Christmas, other things), I find it very strange that this film was a big disappointment at the US box office, while conversely, Big Adventure profited over 40 million dollars. I find it weird, considering this film was directed by the brothers whose filmography at the time consisted of Blood Simple, Miller's Crossing, Raising Arizona, Barton Fink, and Fargo. Sure Big Adventure starred the famous Pee-wee Herman, but in the eyes of the people of 1985 (I should also point out the 13-year difference between the two films), the name printed next to the phrase "Directed By" didn't mean anything. But most of all, I'm baffled by the score this film receives. 80%?. You have overrated films like Pitch Perfect or Perks of Being a Wallflower receiving scores higher than The Big Lebowski, which of course is both an injustice and a travesty. The Big Lebowski is probably the most quotable movie of all time. 

The thing I liked about this movie the most was the script didn't follow the formulaic and safe way writers try to let their screenplay go through. Writers who do that are normally in the fear of their movie getting bad reviews for being too audacious or too raunchy. They're afraid of being criticized by the most esteemed film critics, which of course would lead to negative publicity and disappointing box office. The Coen brothers were no ordinary writers. The last thing did apply to this movie but if I was Joel Coen or Ethan Coen it wouldn't really bother me. Another thing I loved about this film was the darkly comedic performances of the two main stars, Jeff Bridges and John Goodman. Both were very entertaining in their respective and peculiar roles as bowling buddies Jeff "The Dude" Lebowski and Walter Sobchak. Both characters, in my opinion, are legendary and have left a mark on history. And of course, no one can go through a review of The Big Lebowski without mentioning the unforgettable narration by Sam Elliott. The Big Lebowski isn't the same without the deep and gruffly Southern voice introducing us to our laid-back main hero. 

If I were pressed to pick something I disliked about this movie, it would have to be the ultimately unimportant plot. When I first watched The Big Lebowski, there were the eccentric characters, clever dialogue, and unique dream and fantasy sequences. But besides those, there was the unorthodox yet heavy plot that was building around everything, which I found riveting in a weird way (like with Magnolia). *SPOILERS* *SPOILERS* I was kind of disappointed everyone involved with the whole thing excluding The Dude and Walter, who were the titular Big Lebowski, Uli and the Nihilists, and Mrs. Bunny Lebowski, were just scamming each other. Originally, everyone thought that Bunny was captured by the Nihilists and wanted ransom money from Big Lebowski. Big Lebowski wanted The Dude, who he met during a previous conversation about the recent defecation of his rug, to be the courier. The plan was to throw the briefcase over a bridge. But Walter, who The Dude apparently invited to the event, ruins everything with his schemes and throws a bag full of dirty laundry over the bridge instead. But as Maude Lebowski explains to the Dude and as the Dude fully explains to Walter and Donny later on, the nihilists are friends of Bunny and all Bunny actually wants to do is pretend to be kidnapped, ask for ransom money, receive ransom money, and pay her debts all over town, most notably to pornographic tycoon Jackie Treehorn. Treehorn's thugs were also the ones who soiled The Dude's rug while they were looking for the Big Lebowski, who The Dude shares the same name with (Exactly why they got mixed up and went looking for the money at The Dude's house instead of Big Lebowski's, which also led to the soiled rug.) In turn, the Big Lebowski actually wanted Bunny to die because of the difficulty of being married to her. So he put a bunch of useless stuff inside a briefcase, closed it, and called the contents "the money", in hopes of his wife's captors killing her. In turn, the nihilists tried to intimidate both Lebowskis by mailing a toe painted with his wife's green nail polish (the toe actually from one of the nihilists themselves) and crashing into The Dude's home, breaking his stuff, dropping a ferret ("marmot") into Dude's bathtub while he's taking a relaxing bath, and leaving with the threat to cut off Dude's "johnson". Walter actually predicted this kind of stuff to happen, and though these predictions were creative, I didn't want it to happen because it would prove the whole story to be pointless. But I didn't get my wish. I know The Big Lebowski's supposed to be a "Raymond Chandler-esque (dark) comedy crime caper", but I guess Mr. Chandler's work isn't really for me. 

Oh, silly me. I forgot to mention to the effectively creepy yet comedic performance by John Turturro as Jesus Quintana. "You said it man. Nobody fucks with the Jesus." Classic. Anywho, I first watched this movie when I was 20 with my friend. I was the only one who made a sound throughout the whole film. After it, all my friend did was turn to me with a blank face, and expressed his feeling of hate he has whenever there is a dream sequence or surreal scene in movie. He said that he thinks stuff like that are random and stupid, which is probably why he hates David Lynch. He never felt any amazement from surreal films and this one was no different. I called him out, saying that The Big Lebowski is a deeply funny dark comedy, not a Lynchian film just because it had weird dream sequences in it. Then he reminded me of people like Kenneth Turan or Todd McCarthy, people who I will never understand for disliking The Big Lebowski. Overall, great quantities of curse words and ultimately pointless plot aside, The Big Lebowski is filled to the brim with perfectly-timed comedic greatness, unorthodox characters, audacious and sharp dialogue, creative dream sequences, and created one of the most influential, known, and legendary characters of all time, Jeff "The Dude" Lebowski.
My favorite movie! It depicts a man who lives in LA in the '90. He is a slacker and very easygoing.

That the Coens' manage to put it all together into one cohesive but singular picture is a testament to their skill and creativity.

So much love for this film. So many quotes. So many laughs. There's no wonder it's a cult classic, and one with a rabid fan base at that. The Coen Bros. show once again that they are one of the most creative duos working in cinema, going for an all-out original screwball stoner detective comedy rather than trying to recapture the success they found with the dark and edgy "Fargo." This is one of the few comedies I can watch countless times and laugh throughout the entire movie just from remembering what happens next. With its wacky, labyrinthine plot, hilarious dream sequences, unmatched quotes that have "Coen" written all over them, and two of the greatest characters ever written (The Dude and Walter Sobchak), this is definitely the film to beat as the most beloved Coen Bros. film. The Dude abides. And I can take comfort in that.

Steve Buscemi unfortunatly has a very small role, he is an actor that I appreciate and he usually makes me laugh, he had a good role in this movie, but very small, and he was much funnier in other movies, Steve is known from the TV show Boardwalk Empire, he is also known from Fargo, Monsters Inc., Reservoir Dogs and some other movies. Sow, as you can see, this movie has an outstanding cast, wich was necessary to this movie, this movie wouldn't be the same without all of these amazing actors, specially without Bridges and Goodman, who were hilarious and amazing. Overall, one of the best casts for a movie ever.

Jeffrey Lebowski (Jeff Bridges), or how he likes to call himself, The Dude, is a man without job and no obrigations who doesn't care about nothing instead of being at home and playong Bowling tournaments with his best friend Walter Sobchak (Jonh Goodman). Some guys enter to The Dude's house and make him give them the money, that The Dude hasn't got, they leave and pee on his rug. The Dude stays frutrated about it so he visits the other Jeffrey Lebowski who they thought The Dude was. The Dude is ended up to be payed to catch the guys that taked Lebowski's wife giving them a milion dollars. He gets the help of Walter, wich will help him a lot during this trouble. Don't get wrong, this was just 0,01% of the bad things that happened to The Dude, because the other 99,99% are yet to come... Sow, as you can see, this is no amazing plot, i thought it was a bit interesting, but I guess that nowone in the world would have guess that would become to be the script of an amazing movie, it surprisingly worked. A really simple plot that turned out to make the 134th best movie on IMDb's Top 250.

Soundtrack, well, the soundtrack was fantastic, I loved it, there was no themes or anything like that, but there were some amazing songs in lots of scenes, I really enjoyed to hear them and when I watch this movie again, I will be also excited to hear the amazing songs in it. Great choise for this movie's soundtrack, I wouldn't change anything about the soundtrack.

Besides all that, I am now going to tell you what I really thought about this movie. First of all, I can't belive how can someone not like it, I honestly can't thing about something wrong about this movie, it's just one of the best movies of the 90's. It wasn't nominated for an Oscar or Golden Globe, I think that happened just because this is a comedy, but the Awards shoodn't ignore it, this movie is very worth to watch. I'm glad they maked it rated R, the characters cursed a lot and that made them even funnier. Every actor was amazingly chosed to their character, and every actor had amazing perfomances. This is not one of my ten favorite movies, it might be one of my twenty favorite movies, or thirty, or forty, but I'm sure it's one of the fifty best movies I have ever seen. I really loved it and I recommend it to everybody with any age. Overall, this movie is fantastic, it has a simple plot, an outstanding cast, an amazing soundtrack and it's basicly amazing, this is one of my favorite movies and it's one of the best comedy classics ever made with lots of memorable quotes. What actually makes it a good film is the near-perfect casting, which leads to incredible performances by all the main actors.  The story itself really isn't that endearing, but it doesn't have to be.  I would enjoy watching these guys interact during one of their more normal days.  The editing, complete with hypnotic montages and typical Coen style, is as entertaining as it is creative.  The profanity is a little too over the top for my tastes, and like I said, the story itself really kind of sucks, but I can see why this is such a cult classic.

My absolute favorite comedy (as far as laughs go, that is) - Lebowski is memorable, hilarious, and also happens to be a mystery movie! The Coens create a great film which follows The Dude as he is placed in a series of events starting with a pee'd on rug, and leading into run-ins with German Nihilists (bearing a striking resemblance to Krafwerk...), abusive cops, mute brats, a car that gradually becomes more and more disastrously wrecked and, of course, lots of bowling. Genius.

The Big Lebowski is a wicked sharp genre satire disguised as a stoner comedy. It really isn't that hard to pick-up on it, but The Big Lebowski is a modern day version of a film noir. You've got the reclusive male lead (The Dude), the femmeThe Big Lebowski is a wicked sharp genre satire disguised as a stoner comedy. It really isn't that hard to pick-up on it, but The Big Lebowski is a modern day version of a film noir. You've got the reclusive male lead (The Dude), the femme fatales (The trophy wife and the daughter), the mysterious alliance of criminal henchmen (The German nihilists), the decadent businessman (Jackie Treehorn), and the fat, rich, scheming individual who oversees the fates of all those involved (The Big Lebowski). The situation The Big Lebowski gives us is what if you took out the private eye and replaced him with a man so lazy, he is unable to solve any mystery. What the film that shows us is precisely how ridiculous the entire situation is. This is actually even clearer when observing the typical Coen brothers theme, which is finding the humor in the darkest situation (this was proven indefinitely in the brilliant Fargo). Well, film noir literally translates as "dark film" so that means that this is really as dark as you can get outside of the Holocaust (and no, I don't wish the Coens made a comedy about the Holocaust). And boy is it ridiculous when it is shown before us through the eyes of the passive individual. While the satire is brilliant enough, the Coens make it even better with their signature style of idiosyncratic dialogue, and absurdist themes about the nature of life and crime. Inject that with a dose of irony, and The Big Lebowski is the Will Hunting of comedies: He's brilliant, but you sure wouldn't guess it by looking at him.

Add an ensemble cast, the greatest directing duo in Hollywood, and an interesting twist ending, this film remains a cult classic for good reason.

The movie stays a comedy great without forcing laughs upon you, it is smart and well thought out with a story and characters that could easily be stupid and pathetically displayed, but the Coen brothers have portrayed a film that is very interesting with characters portrayed very well and entertainingly, Jeff Bridges is fantastic as our lead character Dude with his carefree attitude and relaxed world being thrown into disarray his change of relaxed and calm is changed drastically with him becoming a man who is absolutely confused and who just wants to go bowling. You will never watch a film quite as entertaining and hilarious as this one. One of the greatest movies ever created.

I'll admit it, I'm not the biggest fan of The Big Lebowski. I think the Coen Brothers have done many much more impressive films in their career (Fargo, The Hudsucker Proxy, No Country for Old Men, A Serious Man), but I'm not blind to itsI'll admit it, I'm not the biggest fan of The Big Lebowski. I think the Coen Brothers have done many much more impressive films in their career (Fargo, The Hudsucker Proxy, No Country for Old Men, A Serious Man), but I'm not blind to its appeal. For one thing it's very funny. For another it's got a great soundtrack. It also features some of the finest performances of John Goodman, John Turturro, Steve Buscemi, Julianne Moore and not forgetting The Dude himself, Jeff Bridges. The plot itself is straight out of film noir, and is complex and multi-layered even by the standards of the genre - in fact, I'm convinced that the only way to make complete sense of the film is to be in a similar state of inebriation and/or being stoned as The Dude. That's one of my main problems with the film (though some might argue that it's part of the charm) - compared to most of the Coen's other work, The Big Lebowski completely lacks focus, and I find that a little irritating. After an hour or so you really couldn't care less what's going to happen, and it just becomes a steady stream of bizarre set-pieces. The film is never dull, but it never really has anything to say either. It may just be a weird series of events stemming from some stoned bum trying to get his rug replaced, which is fine, but a profound comment on everything from modern society to philosophy and religion it is not. But I guess as a cult film it's meant to divide you. I do like the Big Lebowski as a piece of entertainment, but just can't fall passionately in love with it as so many others do - it just doesn't speak to me.

The Big Lebowski" is about an attitude, not a story. It's easy to miss that, because the story is so urgently pursued. It involves kidnapping, ransom money, a porno king, a reclusive millionaire, a runaway girl, the Malibu police, a woman whoThe Big Lebowski" is about an attitude, not a story. It's easy to miss that, because the story is so urgently pursued. It involves kidnapping, ransom money, a porno king, a reclusive millionaire, a runaway girl, the Malibu police, a woman who paints while nude and strapped to an overhead harness, and the last act of the disagreement between Vietnam veterans and Flower Power. It has more scenes about bowling than anything else. This is a plot and dialogue that perhaps only the Coen Brothers  could have devised. I'm thinking less of their clarity in "Fargo" and "No Country for Old Men" than of the almost hallucinatory logic of "Raising Arizona" and "The Hudsucker Proxy." Only a steady hand in the midst of madness allows them to hold it all  together--that, and the delirious richness of their visual approach. Anyone who cares about movies must surely have heard something about the plot. This is a movie that has inspired an annual convention and the Church of the Latter-Day Dude. Its star, Jeff Bridges, has become so identified with the starring role that when he won the 2010 Oscar for Best Actor, Twitterland mourned that his acceptance speech didn't begin with, "The Dude Abides." These words are so emblematic that they inspired a book title, The Dude Abides: The Gospel According to the Coen Brothers, by Cathleen Falsani. This is a serious book, though far from a dreary theological work. The Dude is Jeff Lebowski, an unemployed layabout whose days are spent sipping White Russians and nights are spent at the bowling alley. There is always a little pot available. He has a leonine mane of chestnut hair, a shaggy goatee, and a wardrobe of Bermuda shorts, rummage sale shirts, bathrobes and flip-flops,. He went to Woodstock and never left. He lives in what may be the last crummy run-down low-rent structure in Malibu.  Trust the Dude to find it. It is widely known that the Dude was inspired by a real man named Jeff Dowd, a freelance publicist who was instrumental in launching "Blood Simple" (1984), the first film in the Coen canon. I have long known Jeff Dowd. I can easily see how he might have inspired the Dude. He is as tall, as shaggy and sometimes as mood-altered as Jeff Lebowski, although much more motivated. He remembers names better than a politician, is crafty in his strategies, and burns with a fiery zeal on behalf of those films he consents to represent. In the film, Jeff Lebowski tells the millionaire's daughter (Julianne Moore) that in his youth he helped draft the Port Huron Statement that founded Students for a Democratic Society, and was a member of the Seattle Seven. In real life Jeff Dowd was indeed one of the Seattle Seven, and remains so militant that at Sundance 2009 he took a punch the jaw for insisting too fervently that a critic see "Dirt," an ecological documentary Dowd believed was essential to the survival of the planet. True to his credo of nonviolence, the Dude did not punch back. In "The Big Lebowski," our hero has left politics far behind, and exists primarily to keep a buzz on, and bowl. He is never actually drunk in the movie, and always far from sober. His bowling partners are Walter Sobchak (John Goodman) and Donny Kerabatsos (Steve Buscemi). Walter, even taller than the Dude, is a proud Vietnam veteran and the strategist of the three. He and the Dude never mention politics. Donny is their meek sidekick, always a step behind the big guys. He says perhaps three complete sentences in the film, all brief, and is often interrupted by Walter telling him to shut the f--- up. He is happy to exist on the fringes of their glory. Details of the plot need not concern us. It involves a mean-tempered millionaire in a wheelchair who is the Big Lebowski (the Dude becomes, by logic, the Little Lebowski). He broods before the fire in a vast paneled library, reminding me of no one so much as Major Amberson in "The Magnificent Ambersons." His trophy wife Bunny (Tara Reid) appears to have been kidnapped. This leads indirectly to the Dude being savagely beaten by hit men who mistake him for the Big Lebowski. Well, how many Jeff Lebowskis can there be in Malibu? One of them urinates on The Dude's rug, which he valued highly ("it pulled the room together"), and the whole movie can be loosely described as being about the Dude's attempts to get payback for his rug. The inspiration for the supporting characters can perhaps be found in the novels of Raymond Chandler. The Southern California setting, the millionaire, the kidnapped wife, the bohemian daughter, the enforcers, the cops who know the hero by name, can all be found in Chandler. The Dude is in a sense Philip Marlowe  not in his energy or focus, but in the code he lives by. Down these mean streets walks a man who won't allow his rug to be pissed on. "That will not stand," he says, perhaps unconsciously quoting George H.W. Bush about Saddam's invasion of Kuwait. The Dude does not lie, steal or cheat. He does swear.
